TypeSignature.Value: .class public interface auto ansi abstract IList`1<T> implements class System.Collections.Generic.ICollection`1<!T>, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<!T>, class System.Collections.IEnumerable

Docs.summary: Represents a collection of objects that can be individually accessed by index.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The IList(T) generic interface is a descendant of the <xref:System.Collections.Generic.ICollection%601> generic interface and is the base interface of all generic lists.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance int32 IndexOf(!T item) cil managed

Docs.param: The object to locate in the .
Docs.summary: Determines the index of a specific item in the .
Docs.returns: The index of if found in the list; otherwise, -1.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If an object occurs multiple times in the list, the IndexOf method always returns the first instance found.

MemberSignature.Value: public void Insert (int index, T item);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Insert(int32 index, !T item) cil managed

Docs.param: The zero-based index at which `item` should be inserted.
The object to insert into the .
Docs.summary: Inserts an item to the at the specified index.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If `index` equals the number of items in the <xref:System.Collections.Generic.IList%601>, then `item` is appended to the list.
In collections of contiguous elements, such as lists, the elements that follow the insertion point move down to accommodate the new element. If the collection is indexed, the indexes of the elements that are moved are also updated. This behavior does not apply to collections where elements are conceptually grouped into buckets, such as a hash table.

Docs.exception: is not a valid index in the .

MemberSignature.Value: public T this[int index] { get; set; }

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the element to get or set.
Docs.summary: Gets or sets the element at the specified index.
Docs.value: The element at the specified index.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property provides the ability to access a specific element in the collection by using the following syntax: `myCollection[index]`.
The C# language uses the keyword to define the indexers instead of implementing the Item property. Visual Basic implements Item as a default property, which provides the same indexing functionality.

Docs.exception: is not a valid index in the .
The property is set and the is read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void RemoveAt(int32 index) cil managed

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the item to remove.
Docs.summary: Removes the item at the specified index.

remarks.format: ## Remarks In collections of contiguous elements, such as lists, the elements that follow the removed element move up to occupy the vacated spot. If the collection is indexed, the indexes of the elements that are moved are also updated. This behavior does not apply to collections where elements are conceptually grouped into buckets, such as a hash table.

Docs.exception: is not a valid index in the .
